text: over the last few years there's been a
lot of debate about can you put
regulated data in the cloud and I
suppose the long and short of it is yes
absolutely right but what you need to
put in place are the kind of
compensating controls and mitigating
processes to ensure the safety of that
data or the protection of that data
thinking about the compliance and
regulations that are out there the
biggest challenge really is
interpretation right interpretation not
only for you as cloud users but also for
your kind of certification bodies you
know for people that would in pci-dss a
few years ago it was your auditors
they're needing to know kind of what are
you implementing how you're doing it
what evidential proof have you got that
you've implemented some of these things
so you've got to think about some kind
of approach this at least a logical or a
systematic approach as to compliance and
regs how do you go about complying if
you look at the GDP our kind of
specification it's very woolly in its
language right everything's been written
in terms of legal terms and not
technological terms so you've got no
prescriptive guidance as to what you
should be doing and what you shouldn't
be doing and and what it kind of leads
to is you need to take into account some
kind of framework freight based approach
certainly gdpr doesn't have a framework
so you need to look at some kind of
framework a framework that looks at
privacy that looks at risk management
and then also the controls framework as
well and given you some prescriptive
guidance what we decided to do was
really look at the NIST framework right
so in this framework
it's a multi-tiered risk management and
controls framework it was developed by
the US federal government and really
it's there to give you that top-down
approach
fact that it was done by the u.s. gov
also has got some pedigree to it as well
